Can the truth value of the following sentence be determined using classical logic: More girls have been to Stockholm than he has.Answer Y or N. Only answer with a single letter. Your answer:

data.sampled:
Yes. The statement can be translated into a formal logical system using propositional logic where P(x) represents "More people have been to x than you have" and R(x,y) represents "y has been to x":

∀x (P(x) → R(x,y)) ∧ ¬R(y, y) 

This translates to: "For all x, if more people have been to x than you have, then y has not been to x. And y has not been to x." The right-hand side of the biconditional statement (R(x,y)) is false since it is claimed that no one has been to Milan more times than you. Thus, the implication part (∀x (P(x) → R(x,y))) of the statement is true for the given context.

Yes, this statement can be translated into a formal logical system. The statement "More kids have finished school than you have" can be represented as:
∀x (Kid(x) → FinishedSchool(x)) ∧ ¬∃x (Kid(x) ∧ FinishedSchool(x))

Yes, it is possible to translate this statement into a formal logical system. Here's how it can be expressed in logical form:

∃x (P(x) ∧ ¬P(me))

where ∃x is the existence quantifier, P(x) is a predicate representing "has been to London," and ¬P(me) is the negation of the predicate for "me" (meaning you). The statement "More people have been to London than I have" is equivalent to saying that there exists at least one person who has been to London but not you.
